posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
We’re trying to perfect the turn-to-angle for our swerve drive. The swerve is fully CTR-based (falcons + cancoders+Pigeon2), and has a Pro license in case we need to pull sensors more often.

We would like to be able to implement the precise turn-to-angle from a stopped position with tolerance of half-degree.

Right now we’re trying to use the profilePIDController with trapezoid profile. However,  we could greatly benefit on advice of handling static friction. So, the turn essentially is done as a call to a"drive" method that works with SwerveChassis class (meaning - we do not operate with wheel motors directly - maybe that’s a mistake and we should?)

We essentially use equivalent of joystick inputs to move the robot (meaning - the PID really generates that, we translate that into velocities based on the max angular velocity and assuming that dependency on joystick vs velocity is linear). So, we also also that a joystick input that starts robot moving is 0.02. However, to keep it going it needs to be above 0.015. So, we ping IMU every cycle and recalculate the necessary input in a profile based on that. I do not really think this is the best way to do it. And so I’d like some input from the community.

Another way would be, for instance, is to calculate how much the wheels need to turn, and do a Position PID on the wheel motors once they’re turned to the right angle. The idea is that the length of the motion is fairly small (e.g. angles to turn will generally be 30 degrees or less; any bigger ones can be done with the trajectory controller, like PathPlanner, but for in-place turns its error is often around 3 degrees). So, we’re trying to really adjust the turns of, say 5 degree clockwise. We found those to be important with precision shooting at a distance. Our cameras, when combined, can get us pretty reliable angular and fairly reliable linear positions.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: We use a profiled PID controller as well, using yaw angle as the input, and omega radians per second (from the chassis speeds object) as the output. In fact, we’re always running PID on our rotation, and our rotation stick just adjusts the setpoint. Though that PID loop isn’t profiled, but our aiming ones are.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
Could you provide a reference to a code, please?

We actually did run quasistatic SysId loop on the turns based on the joystick input. Do not know how good the PID constants are that are determined that way, but we will try.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
We’re not actually running any feed forward for that PID .

GitHub - lasarobotics/PH2024: 2024 Purple Haze FRC 2024 Purple Haze FRC

2024 Purple Haze FRC

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
viggy96
posts.cooked:
Yes those are joystick inputs, which is why that makes out at 1, and it’s multiplied by the “DRIVE_TURN_SCALAR” to determine how much to move the setpoint by.

So in this example, when the driver pushes the rotate stick all the way, the setpoint is set to 90 degrees from the current IMU value.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
Got it. In our case the drivers are used to do manual rotation where the rotation joystick indicates “degree of rotation power” (in other word, if that joystick is held, the robot will spin continuously).

So, since in my case I am only looking for automated turns, am I correct and I do not really need to subclass PIDController, like you did? It appears while in your case the “calculate” takes momentary angular velocity into consideration, it does not use it to calculate the the actual requested velocity.

I also did not seem to see the code that would handle the “last mile” precision handling, where you’re not at the position, and the robot does not seem to move based on whatever number you calculated (due to friction).

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Like I said, we use a regular profiled PID controller for aiming at objects. You can see this in aimAtPoint method. Using this method, we can aim at any arbitrary coordinate on the field, and it worked to great effect to aim at the speaker.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked: I will try it. As I said, my main issue was - the friction seems too high, so for small angles the controller would generate a gain that would not actually move the robot. The velocity PID does not really help much here as velocity gains are translated into voltages or duty cycle settings anyway. And if a given voltage would sustain the robot moving, but not start the move, a simple PID controller does not define such behavior well. That may be a defect of the build, but I am trying to see if there is a model that can deal with such issue.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
I believe your issue is more mechanical. What level of accuracy are you looking for? <2 degrees, <1 degree?

A regular position PID controller should be more than sufficient to accurately rotate the robot to your desired orientation.

Are you guys using closed loop control on your swerve modules (velocity PID for drive motors)?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: I think the confusion here is that OP is asking about including friction in the top level pose theta controller, which is the wrong level to worry about friction.  you should be using a friction term in your low level motor control, and using closed loop velocity control there, so if the top level controller produces a velocity command, it will be obeyed, even if it’s small.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Ah I see. Indeed, that is the right place to do it.

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked:
atsekhan:

with tolerance of half-degree

I think it’s nearly impossible to get 0.5 degrees of accuracy in FRC .  if you’re trying to aim at a shooter target, 2 degrees of tolerance is what I would go for instead.   We had five cameras running 720p April tag detection with photo vision; we still have around 2 degrees of error margin for rotation.

atsekhan:

However, to keep it going it needs to be above 0.015.

You could try turning up the friction gain of the feed-forward controller for your driving motor a bit.

atsekhan:

Another way would be, for instance, is to calculate how much the wheels need to turn, and do a Position PID on the wheel motors once they’re turned to the right angle.

I’ve never heard someone do that. When rotating your chassis, the driving wheels should be turning at the same speed; they shouldn’t be running separate position PIDs.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
I may be mistaken, but the low level control done via SwerveDrive class of CTR does not have a friction component. We looked into the actual library code, and it appears to convert velocity into direct voltage, that’s about it. In other words, if you tell the chassis to run with a low velocity, it will NOT move. We’re trying to simplify our swerve code from last year (where we did all of the code, including low-level one) and see if we can get the code smaller.

For instance, the code that was given as a reference, the drive is done via swervemodulestates - import org.lasarobotics.drive.MAXSwerveModule; and the actual command to drive is set here:

m_driveMotor.set(m_desiredState.speedMetersPerSecond, ControlType.kVelocity);

With the CTR library, however, the drive is essentially done like this -

The library code does the drive requests like this -

The actual code that makes the wheels move inside the library looks like this:

The library class that handles it is VelocityVoltage indeed appears to have an ability to set a voltage PID . But with very low velocities it just does not seem to happen, ever. Any ideas how to troubleshoot that?

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
We easily get 3 degrees or less about 90% of the time with properly tuned PathPlanner on-the-fly trajectory. However, shooting from far distances requires substantially better precision. An error of 3 degrees at 3 meters gets you 0.26 target deviation. That’s quite substantial, considering that the cameras and other devices would also have their own errors. Compounding all these errors may get you to 10 degrees or so, which will make it miss the target. We did not test LL megapose2 that claims to be much more precise this year, though. But even then the drive of the robot usually introduces enough jitter in the camera stand to cause 2-3 degree deviation, which may be compounded.

I still think that with proper PID on low turn speed you can get such precision of 0.5 degree (per IMU setting), if you would be Ok with low speeds (e.g. allocate 1.5 seconds per, say, 20 degree or less turn)

Re: driving wheels and the same speed - they’re still issued separate commands inside individual swerve modules. They definitely do not run with the same momentary speed in a holonomic movement. Since the commands change often you do not really see the jitter. But one chassis motor definitely does not watch the other ones.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Set the kS gain to an appropriate value and you will have stiction compensation.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: We made a switch from using a profiledPIDController to using a normal PIDController with a custom acceleration limitation on top of it. The issue with profiledPIDController is that its “profile” is not very accurate, especially with acceleration. Since the magnitude of the acceleration and deceleration is the same for profiledPIDController, our robot can’t keep up with high acceleration, but low acceleration will make small adjustments very slow. Additionally, to achieve accurate aiming, I recommend tracking the tag on the speaker and using the relative angle to aim. This is because other tags might be slightly off, and pose estimation will have some error in it. If you’re calculating the pose and then the angle, why not just directly calculate the angle?

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
I do not think the ProfiledPIDController or PIDController classes have kS. However, there is withDriveFrictionVoltage in SwerveModuleConstantsFactory . But the documentation appears to state it’s for simulation? May be someone from CTR would clarify that.

Or you mean using SimpleMotorFeedforward and combine the output with PID ? That one indeed has kS, and that’s the one I was going to try next.

posts.name: Alex Tsekhansky
posts.cooked:
Could you share the code for the subclassed controller?

I think that’s exactly what I may be looking for, for the exact reasons you stated.

Re: accurate aiming - yes, we’re doing exactly that. We generally only uses chassis poses for auto-driving, not for aiming-when-stopped.  That’s why turn-to-angle would be a command separate from driving.

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked:
The code looks like this: image 2333×876 212 KB It is an open-loop operation. We found that if you make it close-loop by replacing the current desired chassis angular speed with the actual angular speed, and your controller isn’t very accurate, it will not work. For example, if the desired speed is 2 rad/s, but your robot goes up to 3 rad/s, and the algorithm tries to slow it down by setting it to 2.5 rad/s, it will actually go faster.
